(30)).Pursuing the subject of an Import Board, and taking up the questions propounded by the Chancellorof the Exchequer in C^-oOS (30), the cabinet agreed that, if created, an Import Eoard would beof the nature of a statutory body and not a department of Government controlled, by the Cabinet.or by the Head of a Department of the Government.In regard to the third group of questions propoundedby the Chancellor of the Exchequer, namely, as towhat would be the effect of an Import Board on imperial relations, the trend of opinion was tothe effect that friction would be difficult to avoid,Moreover, it was realised that it wo v. The Prime Minister summed up the discussion by stating that while, theoretically, there was agreat deal to be said for an Import Board, it wouldin ^act be extremely difficult to establish it ona full-sized scale. It would, therefore, be better to start with something which might develop laterinto an Import Board.The Cabinet felt that until the australian government, at whose instance this question hadbeen placed on the Agenda Paper, had developedits proposals in detail, it was impossible for themto reach any final decisions, and that the utmostthat could be done was to formulate, in relation tothe Imperial Conference, the essentials of theUnited Kingdom in regard to Import Boards.In the circumstances the Cabinet felt that better prospects of progress were opened up bysome of the suggestions contained in the Memorandumby the President of the Board of Trade on ImperialTrade Policy and Imperial Economic Machinery(C .P. 504 (30)). It was suggested that vhat was required was to establish machinery for a morecontinuous study of Empire trade. In the politicalsphere this .might be achieved by meetings, to be heldin london or elsewhere as might be arranged, inconnection with the annual visits of Empire repre-sentatives to the Assembly of the League at Geneva.To facilitate the preparation for such meetings,the establishment of som,e form of ImperialSecretariat, analogous to the economic side of theLeague of Nations Secretariat, was deemed desirable.Such a Secretariat, it was thought, might "'orm aoonnectin-v link between such existing bodies as the Imperial Shipping Committee, the ImperialEconomic Committee, the Empire Marketing Boardand the Imperial Institute. The existence ofthe Secretariat would make it easier for allconcerned to follow the work of these separateImperial bodies.
